author: @statquest
text: NOTE: Conditional probabilities can be written two ways: a "long" version and a "short" version. In this video I use the long version (because it's easier for me to read)... P(A and B | B) = P(A and B)/P(B) ...however, the short version is commonly used... P(A | B) = P(A and B)/P(B) Both mean the same thing, in other words: P(A and B | B) = P(A | B). The short version implies the "and B" part.  Support StatQuest by buying my book The StatQuest Illustrated Guide to Machine Learning or a Study Guide or Merch!!! https://statquest.org/statquest-store/

author: @mikejohns1347
text: I "stumbled" upon the contingency table method many years ago when trying teach myself the basics of probability. This approach is really the only approach for developing a solid understanding of conditional probability, as well as joint and marginal probability. I've never seen anyone present it this way and I'm so glad to see it here! Just more evidence that Josh Starmer is an absolute master instructor.

author: @Nakameguro97
text: Thank you SO MUCH for clarifying that AB = A and B, when A and B are events.  I get confused because XY is literally multiplication when X and Y are random variables.  It can be doubly confusing because both events and random variables (even though they are different types) can be passed into P(), the probability function.  Function overloading is a thing in computer programming, but I‚Äôm shocked to see it in math.  Also, the implied A and B in P(A | B) is a lifesaver, many times over.  BTW, understanding the tables in this video is pivotal in grasping marginal distributions, Baye‚Äôs Theorem, and joint probability distributions - it feels like I‚Äôm getting the other three concepts for free!

text: NOTE: Conditional probabilities can be written two ways: a "long" version and a "short" version. In this video I use the long version (because it's easier for me to read)... P(A and B | B) = P(A and B)/P(B) ...however, the short version is commonly used... P(A | B) = P(A and B)/P(B) Both mean the same thing, in other words: P(A and B | B) = P(A | B). The short version implies the "and B" part. author: @sinecurve9999
text: Conditional probability is Bayes theorem in disguise. P(loves candy and soda | loves soda) = P(loves soda | loves candy and soda)*P(loves candy and soda)/P(loves soda). P(loves soda | loves candy and soda) =1, so P(loves candy and soda | loves soda) = P(loves candy and soda)/P(loves soda).
